Corporate ID: FRN 0017190224 
Document Control No.: Page 1 of 2 

REDACTED – FOR PUBLIC INSPECTION 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION 

 
Response to General Information Request 

Regarding the AST Telecom, LLC d/b/a/ Bluesky/Club 42 Transaction 
Response to Question Posed to Club 42 CM Limited Partnership 

WT Docket No. 16-264 
Assignment of Licenses Application File No. 0007294780 

 
Response of Club 42 CM Limited Partnership 

 
 
FCC Interrogatory No. 1: Explain in detail the decision made by Club 42 to assign the Lower 
700 MHz B and Lower 700MHz E Block licenses that are the subject of this application to 
Bluesky, including any attempts made to enter into a sale of this spectrum or alternative 
arrangements with parties other than Bluesky. 
 
Response to FCC Interrogatory No. 1:  The decision to sell the two licenses to AST Telecom, 
LLC d/b/a Bluesky (“Bluesky”) was based upon the following factors:   [BEGIN REDACTION

REDACTED – FOR PUBLIC INSPECTION 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION 

 
Response to General Information Request 

Regarding the AST Telecom, LLC d/b/a/ Bluesky/Club 42 Transaction 
Response to Question Posed to Club 42 CM Limited Partnership 

WT Docket No. 16-264 
Assignment of Licenses Application File No. 0007294780 

 
Club 42 did not consider any alternative arrangements (e.g., spectrum leasing, management 
contracts, etc.) with any companies or individuals.  [BEGIN REDACTION * * * * * * * * * * *

Law Offices of Robert M. Jackson 
614 Goldsborough Drive 

Rockville, MD 20850 
Tel: 240-672-4705 

E-mail: rmjlaw1974@hotmail.com  
 

October 5, 2016 
 

REDACTED – FOR PUBLIC INSPECTION 
 
Marlene H. Dortch, Secretary 
Federal Communications Commission 
445 12th Street, S.W.  
Washington, D.C. 20554 
 
 
 Re: Response of Club 42 CM Limited Partnership,  

       WT Docket No. 16-264, 
       Application of AST Telecom, LLC d/b/a Bluesky and 
       Club 42CM Limited Partnership for Consent to Assign Licenses. 

 
Dear Ms. Dortch: 
 
 On behalf of Club 42CM Limited Partnership, I am transmitting herewith its 
Redacted Response to the Wireless Telecommunications Bureau’s General 
Information Request in the referenced proceeding.  The Response filed manually 
through the Office of the Secretary contains Confidential Information. 
 
 Please refer any inquiries or correspondence in connection with this matter 
to me. 
 
       Very truly yours, 
 
        /s/ 
 
       Robert M. Jackson 

Attorney for Club 42CM 
Limited Partnership 

Attachment

proceedings.description: Implementation of the Pay Telephone Reclassification and Compensation Provisions of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 et al.

filings.browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; Trident/7.0; rv:11.0) like Gecko
filings.text_data: 1  BEFORE THE  FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION WASHINGTON, D.C.20554  NETWORK COMMUNICATIONS INTERNATIONAL CORP. * PUBLIC NOTICE DA-296 (?NCIC?)        * WC Docket No. 12-375          * In Re: Rates for Interstate Inmate Calling Services - *   Comments sought on Requests for Limited Waiver * of Inmate Calling Services Rate Caps  * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *    COMMENTS ON ADDITIONAL REQUESTS FOR LIMITED WAIVER OF ITS INMATE CALLING SERVICE RATE CAPS   NOW COMES Network Communications International Corp. (hereinafter ?NCIC?) who files these Comments in response to the FCC request for comments for Limited Waiver of Its Inmate Calling Service Rate Caps - Rates for Interstate Inmate Calling Services. The FCC seeks comments on two petitions filed by Securus Technologies, Inc. concerning its inmate calling service rate caps.  NCIC hereby supports Securus? request that the nine-month waiver and $.46 rate cap that was granted to Pay Tel be granted to all providers of Inmate Calling Services serving county facilities located in the same states as Pay Tel.   NCIC concurs with Securus? position that all ICS providers operating in those states are subject to the same expenses as Pay Tel.  NCIC hereby also supports Securus? request to allow a $.02 per minute Voice Biometrics Fee to be added to the interstate rates in order to recoup the cost of providing such technology required for secure inmate calling.     2  Respectfully submitted, /s/William L. Pope William L. Pope, President Network Communications International Corp. 606 East Magrill  Longview, Texas 75601 Telephone: (903) 757-4455 bpope@ncic.com

proceedings.description: Applications of Cricket License Company, LLC, et al., Leap Wireless International, Inc. and AT&T Inc. for Consent To Transfer Control of Authorizations; Application of Cricket License Company, LLC and Leap Licenseco Inc. for Assignment of Authorization

filings.text_data: 1300 NORTH 17th STREET, 11th FLOOR ARLINGTON, VIRGINIA  22209  OFFICE:  (703) 812-0400 FAX:  (703) 812-0486 www.fhhlaw.com www.commlawblog.com               DONALD J. EVANS (703) 812-0430 evans@fhhlaw.com February 14, 2014  Via Electronic Filing  Marlene H. Dortch, Secretary Federal Communications Commission 445 12th Street, S.W. Washington, DC 20554  Re: Written Ex Parte Presentation; Applications of Cricket License Company, LLC, et al., Leap Wireless International, Inc., and AT&T Inc. for Consent To Transfer Control of Authorizations, WT Docket 13-193  REDACTED VERSION ? FOR PUBLIC INSPECTION  Dear Ms. Dortch:  Youghiogheny Communications, LLC, by its undersigned attorney, is submitting the enclosed REDACTED ex parte response.  The full unredacted version of the ex parte response is being filed by hand delivery under separate cover.  Copies of the unredacted ex parte report are also being delivered to Brigid Calamis of the Wireless Telecommunications Bureau.   Should you have any questions, please contact the undersigned.           Sincerely,        /s/ Donald J. Evans        Counsel for Youghiogheny Communications, LLC  Enclosure  cc (via email):  Best Copy and Printing, Inc. Jim Bird Hillary Burchuk Brigid Calamis AJ Glusman Kathy Harris David Krech Kate Matraves Linda Ray John Schauble Susan Singer      1300 NORTH 17th STREET, 11th FLOOR ARLINGTON, VIRGINIA  22209  OFFICE:  (703) 812-0400 FAX:  (703) 812-0486 www.fhhlaw.com www.commlawblog.com               DONALD J. EVANS (703) 812-0430 evans@fhhlaw.com February 14, 2014 {00623991-1 }  Via Electronic Filing  Marlene H. Dortch, Secretary Federal Communications Commission 445 12th Street, S.W. Washington, DC 20554  Re: Ex Parte Response to Supplemental Information; Applications of Cricket License Company, LLC, et al., Leap Wireless International, Inc., and AT&T Inc. for Consent To Transfer Control of Authorizations, WT Docket 13-193   REDACTED VERSION ? FOR PUBLIC INSPECTION    Dear Ms. Dortch:   In its first Information and Discovery Request to AT&T in November, 2013, the Commission asked in Request 15(b) for detailed information about how Leap's existing Lifeline customers would be transitioned.   It has been like pulling teeth to get a straight and complete story from AT&T about this issue.  Since November, AT&T has submitted a number of supplemental responses addressing this issue incompletely.  It has stressed its confidence that Leap's current customers (who have so far deliberately chosen not to be AT&T customers) will see the light and convert.  It has also pointed to the fact that other carriers offer Lifeline service in some of the markets where Leap currently offers it, so Leap customers can presumably transition over to those carriers.  It has also made it clear that it will not be offering Lifeline service over its GSM  facilities once Leap's CDMA network is switched out, which may be in as little as 12 months.  This response, in our view, glosses over a serious negative impact to the public from the proposed transaction and highlights the need for further formal steps to be taken before the plan can be lawfully implemented.   The USAC website indicates that Leap received $5,366,374 in Lifeline reimbursement in January, 2014.   Dividing that number by the per subscriber monthly Lifeline subsidy of $9.25 indicates that Leap currently has approximately 580,149 Lifeline subscribers -- more than 10% of its subscriber base.   This high proportion of Lifeline users is not surprising since the Lifeline program is especially popular in the market segment that needs or prefers pre-paid or advance   Marlene H. Dortch, Secretary  Federal Communications Commission  February 14, 2014  Page 2   {00623991-1 }  REDACTED VERSION ? FOR PUBLIC INSPECTION  pay service due to credit issues or simply low income status.  Often the Lifeline subsidy is the difference between the subscriber being able to afford a phone and not being able to.     [BEGIN HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION] *              * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *   * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *   * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *                                                                                                                                       * [END HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION]    AT&T's apparent solution to this problem -- offered only after the Commission prodded it for more information about its plans for Lifeline transition -- is to offer to effectively subsidize   Marlene H. Dortch, Secretary  Federal Communications Commission  February 14, 2014  Page 3   {00623991-1 }  REDACTED VERSION ? FOR PUBLIC INSPECTION  Lifeline subscribers itself as long as the customer does not take any of the sort of actions often taken by prepaid subscribers, such as suspending service temporarily.  As Youghiogheny has previously pointed out, prepaid customers often suspend service for brief periods for financial or other reasons, so this opens a large avenue for AT&T to be able to cut those customers off from continuation on their low cost or subsidized rate plans.    [BEGIN HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION] *                    * * * * * * * *                                                                                           * [END HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION]  Yet AT&T's migration plan confidently and repeatedly assumes and predicts that Leap customers will happily migrate over to AT&T's superior plans.   For subsistence-level Lifeline customers, $9.25/mo. is huge.   [BEGIN HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION] *      * * * * * * * * *                                                                                           *   * * * * * * * * * * * *   * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *                                                    * [END HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION]    Marlene H. Dortch, Secretary  Federal Communications Commission  February 14, 2014  Page 4   {00623991-1 }  REDACTED VERSION ? FOR PUBLIC INSPECTION   AT&T has offered lengthy responses on how it is going to try to transition Leap customers to the AT&T network, but those remarkably rosy projections about Leap's customers' embrace of AT&T prices and terms of service fail to address the plight of the hundreds of thousands of Lifeline subscribers for whom, [BEGIN HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION] *                                                                                   * [END HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION ]  a transition to AT&T will be fiscally impossible.   This half a million customer population is too large to be ignored or brushed away like an afterthought.   The Applicants should therefore be required to provide detailed information on 1) how many Lifeline subscribers Leap has, 2) how many of them are in CMAs where there is no alternative wireless Lifeline provider or no alternative CDMA provider, 3) how the Applicants intend to comply with their obligations under Sections 54.405 and 54.205 of the rules, and 4) how Lifeline customers who do not have a CDMA alternative will be transitioned to an alternate service provider.  In addition, the Commission should make the [BEGIN HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION] *                                                       * [END HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION] a part of the public record in this Docket and give members of the public a fair opportunity to comment on the plan and how it will affect them.         Respectfully submitted,        Youghiogheny Communications, LLC         By:_______/s/_______________                Donald J. Evans                  Its Attorney

proceedings.description: Applications of Comcast Corporation and Time Warner Cable Inc. for Consent to Assign or Transfer Control of Licenses and Applications

filings.text_data: 7521798878.txtMonopolies used to be illegal. There were reasons for that:  * Competition is eliminated * Consumer choice is eliminated * Jobs are lost * Prices increase * Quality decreases * Customer service is no longer necessary * The little guys are put out of business  Reason for Monopolies: * Corporate greed  We're down to only one or two banks, grocery stores, dept. stores, hardware stores, etc. and it has notbeen good for the economy or the consumer. Stop the madness. Page 1

text_data: . There were reasons for that: * Competition is

is the subject of this application to TeleGuam, including any attempts made toenter into a sale of this spectrum or alternative arrangements with parties other than TeleGuam.Response to FCC proceedings.description: Implementation of the Pay Telephone Reclassification and Compensation Provisions of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 et al.

filings.browser: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; Trident/6.0)
filings.text_data: 1  BEFORE THE  FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION WASHINGTON, D.C.20554  NETWORK COMMUNICATIONS INTERNATIONAL CORP. * (?NCIC?)        * WC Docket No. 12-375          * DA 13-1445 In Re: Rates for Interstate Inmate Calling Services and  *   Ancillary Fees   * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *    REPLY COMMENTS ON NOTICE OF PROPOSED RULEMAKING  Network Communications International Corp. (hereinafter ?NCIC?) wishes to fervently demonstrate its plea that the Commission defer the decision to implement a lower, proposed interstate rate to jails, short-term holding facilities and short-term immigration detainment centers.  It is fundamentally imperative that further analysis and consideration of security costs directly associated with providing short-term ICS are thoroughly exhausted prior to making a final order.  Please consider the mental, physical and financial stress that will undoubtedly ensue within facilities/facility staff as massive arbitrage occurs, leading to substantial security risks, therefore forcing facilities to limit inmate calling due to insufficient time to take preventative measures.   NCIC specifically requests that the application of the imposed interstate rate structure for jails correspond with the action on the Future Notice of Proposed Rule Making (hereinafter ?FNPRM?) and that the FNPRM be acted on within 180 days.  Should the Commission address 2  ancillary fees, it is essential that a cost based payment structure be acceptable and that the administrative and security costs of ICS incurred by jails and short-term facilities be recoverable through a permissible recovery mechanism. NCIC urges the Commission to fully consider all the information provided before coming to a decision in this Order.  Respectfully submitted, ______/s/William L. Pope________    William L. Pope, President Network Communications International Corp. 606 East Magrill  Longview, Texas 75601 Telephone: (903) 757-4455 bpope@ncic.com

In order to proceed with our review of your complaint, we need to understand your connection to Europe. If you reside in Europe, you may attach a copy of an identification document (passports or government documents are not required) in response to this email. Otherwise, please explain the connection you have to one or more European countries. We will continue processing your request once we receive additional verification. We will not be able to process your complaint without this information.: my name is NOT on this page at all. Neeley Jr. ==/\=end response & request for further info==/\= * = Live PDF LINKS

filings.text_data: 7521802790.txtThis merger is a customer nightmare that will:  * Limit competition  * Set the stagefor yet another \Too Big to Fail\ situation in which the taxpayers will bear the burden  * Jeopardize Net Neutrality  * Leave the door open to squash fledgling streaming companies  * Raise my rates  * Limit my viewing options  * Limit what political voices get heard  etc. etc. etc. . .  Look what's already happened in the media outlet industry: it has become hugely concentrated.  I cannot see one advantage this merger will bring to myself or any other customer Page 1

filings.browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:29.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/29.0
filings.text_data: 7521133394.txt* * * Chairman Wheeler's proposal undercuts net neutrality and would favor wealthy corporations by allowing 'pay to play' rules to stifle small businesses. This proposal is bad for consumers, bad for the next generation of businesses, and bad for the future of our democracy. * * * American consumers have been clear: The way forward is to regulate Internet providers like telephone companies.Page 1
